title-group.article-title: Macroscopically uniform interface layer with Li+ conductive channels for high-performance Li metal batteries

contrib-group.aff: 2https://ror.org/00wk2mp56grid.64939.310000 0000 9999 1211School of Materials Science and Engineering, Beihang University, Beijing, 100191 China

abstract.p: The numerous grainboundaries solid electrolyte interface, whether naturally occurring or artificially designed, leads to non-uniform Li metal deposition and consequently results in poor full-battery performance. Herein, a lithium-ion selective transport layer is reported to achieve a highly efficient and dendrite-free lithium metal anode. The layer-by-layer assembled protonated carbon nitride nanosheets present uniform macroscopical structure without grainboundaries. The carbon nitride with ordered pores in basal plane provides high-speed lithium-ion transport channels with low tortuosity. Consequently, the assembled 324 Wh kg−1 pouch cell exhibits 300 stable cycles with a capacity retention of 90.0% and an average Coulombic efficiency up to 99.7%. The ultra-dense Li metal anode makes current collector-free anode possible, achieving high energy density and long cycle life of a 7 Ah cell (506 Wh kg−1, 160 cycles). Thus, it is proved that a macroscopically uniform interface layer with lithium-ion conductive channels could achieve Li metal battery with promising application potential.

Here, authors report a macroscopical grain boundary-free interface layer with microscopic Li + -selective conductive channels enables the ultra-dense Li metal deposition, resulting in a high energy density (506 Wh kg−1) and long cycle life (160 cycles) pouch cell performance.

institution-wrap.institution: National Natural Science Foundation of China (National Science Foundation of China)

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Lithium (Li) metal is considered as the ultimate anode material to replace graphite anode in high-energy-density rechargeable batteries1–3. Paring with high areal capacity cathode ( > 6 mAh cm−2) and low electrolyte injection factor ( < 1.5 g Ah−1), it is feasible to attain a high energy density Li metal pouch cell ( > 450 Wh kg−1). Unfortunately, due to the growth of Li dendrite, infinite volume expansion, side reactions with electrolyte and pulverization during cycles, high energy density Li metal pouch cell will usually meet the sudden failure problem after certain cycles, making it still far away from practical applications4,5.

The key to regulating the lithium metal anodes (LMAs) lies in optimizing the design of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layers6. The conventional interface can regularly be described by “Mosaic” SEI model (Fig. 1a). The various inorganic and organic SEI components produced by the irreversible reduction decomposition of electrolytes are randomly distributed on the surface of Li metal. Due to the different energy barriers of Li+ transport, this distribution will make an uneven Li+ flux in the interface layer, resulting in Li dendrite growth and the consumption of electrolyte.Fig. 1Schematic of Li+ transport process with and without protective layer.
a The Li deposition behavior and “Mosaic” SEI. b 2D materials protective layer coating on Li metal by (i) common 2D materials; (ii) Li+ selective conduction 2D materials. The green spheres represent Li ions and the yellow clusters represent anions.

To solve these problems, constructing artificial SEI layer with high Li+ transport speed and uniform Li+ flux have been applied to induce uniform deposition of Li metal7. Meanwhile, the development of high energy density Li metal pouch cells necessitates a large-scale and uniformly implemented modification approach to enhance the performance of Li metal8,9. Commencing from these points, coating a modified layer on Li metal can not only address the scientific challenges associated with LMAs but also overcome the practical hurdles in scaling up modifications for LMAs.

Common coatings for Li metal anodes encompass inorganic materials (metal fluorides10, metal sulfides11 and so on12), organic materials (PDMS13, PEO14, PMMA15 and so on16), and inorganic-organic hybrid materials17,18. These coating layers can effectively protect the LMAs from directly contact with electrolyte. Nevertheless, inorganic components are usually difficult to disperse uniformly on the surface of Li metal, and most of the polymer coatings with single component struggle to suppress the growth of Li dendrites. Inorganic-organic layer can effectively solve those problems, but they also face issues such as diminished Li+ conductivity and phase separation in the layer, which restrict their further practical applicability18.

Considering the planar structure and unique properties of two-dimensional (2D) materials, it is conceivable and feasible to construct an artificial SEI layer on the surface of LMAs19–21. The layer-by-layer assembly of 2D nanosheets on Li metal can realize a macroscopically uniform interface structure and hinder the contact of electrolyte with Li metal (Fig. 1b(i)). However, the high tortuosity of this structure will increase Li+ transport path distance, eventually leading to the poor battery dynamics and increase of interface impendence22. Therefore, it is necessary to select 2D materials with specific microstructures that can facilitate the transport of Li+.

Graphitic Carbon Nitride (g-C3N4), with surface-rich chemical active sites and in-plane porous structure, can effectively enhance Li+ transport behavior (Supplementary Table 1)23–27. On this basis, we further processed g-C3N4 into protonated carbon nitride (PCN) nanosheets to obtain more microporous structure and better dispersibility in the coating layer. Besides, PEO polymer, with high ionic conductivity, Li metal compatibility and excellent diversification to PCN, is chosen to evenly dispersed PCN nanosheets to form PCN-PEO protective layer on Li metal. The pores in the PCN molecular structure can form a unique Li+-selective transport pathway with low tortuosity, thus providing more conducive and more uniform Li+ transport channels than other inorganic fillers (Fig. 1b(ii)).

As a result, the modification of Li metal with PCN-PEO protective layer provides a feasible approach to realize ultra-dense and smoothy Li plating can make Li metal foil as both anode and current collector (CC), pushing the energy density of the full cell to its limit. The 324 Wh kg−1 pouch cell can achieve more than 300 stable cycles with a capacity retention of 90.0%, indicating great prospects for further practical application in LMBs. The CC-free anode can further push the energy density of pouch cell to 506.7 Wh kg−1, for which 170 stable cycles can be realized.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
The PCN nanosheets were first produced by protonating yellow g-C3N4 powder in saturated HCl solution and further exfoliating by high-power probe sonication in a conical tube (Supplementary Figs. 1, 2)28,29. The typical nanosheet morphology of obtained amorphous carbon nitride was observed by transmission electron microscope (TEM) (Supplementary Fig. 3). Atomic force microscopy (AFM) image (Fig. 2a and Supplementary Fig. 4) revealed that the lateral size of the PCN nanosheet was less than 1 μm and the thickness was about 4 nm ( ~ 60 nm and 3 μm for g-C3N4), demonstrating this method was valid for exfoliating g-C3N4 into the small lateral size and ultrathin PCN nanosheets. The pore size distribution displayed that PCN nanosheets exhibited more micropores ( ~ 0.7 nm) compared to g-C3N4, indicating the microporous nature of the PCN structure (Fig. 2b). These sub-nanosized pores could effectively block Li salt anions by size limitation, thus forming a Li+-selective conduction interface to accelerate the transport of Li+ and reduce the interfacial reaction between Li metal and electrolyte. Besides, the Zeta potential of PCN nanosheet was 24.6 mV in contrast to −22.41 mV of g-C3N4 powder, which confirmed the introduction of proton (Supplementary Fig. 5). The XRD patterns of PCN nanosheet revealed that (002) peak was much weaker and broader, and (100) peak disappeared, indicating that the stacking of the conjugated aromatic systems and the in-plane repeat units of PCN were disrupted after the exfoliation (Supplementary Fig. 6)30. Meanwhile, the XPS peaks of N 1 s and C 1 s in PCN nanosheet moved up to higher binding energies compared to those in g-C3N4, confirming proton introduction in the structure of carbon nitride (Supplementary Fig. 7 and Table 2).Fig. 2Li+ selectivity of PCN protective layer.
a AFM image of PCN nanosheet. b Pore size distribution of g-C3N4 and PCN based on N2 adsorption/desorption data. The green spheres represent Li+ and the yellow clusters represent anions. c The Li+ diffusion energy barrier through the PCN system. d Initial model of PCN/electrolyte/PCN. e Variations of energy and (f) temperature against the time for molecular dynamics simulations of PCN system. g Snapshot of atomic configurations.

Theoretical simulation and calculation were applied to further verify the Li+-selective conduction of PCN nanosheets. Three typical H doping sites of PCN configurations were explored. The results (Supplementary Fig. 8) showed that the most stable configuration for PCN is the H doping adjacent to the nitrogen sites of the triangular pores. Then, this model was adopted to investigate the adsorption behavior of Li+ on PCN. The most stable adsorption sites of Li+ in both CN and PCN were N atoms sites in the triangular pore sites (Supplementary Fig. 9). The charge density differences and Bader charge analysis revealed that 0.08 e transfer from CN to Li+, while this value was 0.06 e in the PCN adsorption system. The results showed that PCN system with less electrons interaction possesses a higher Li+ Ead (−2.32 eV) than that value CN (−6.35 eV). Previous work has identified that the decreased binding energy to Li+ facilitates the kinetics behavior31,32. H doping can alleviate the intense interaction between the adsorbed Li ion and inherent nitrogen atoms in the triangular pores thus decreasing the Li diffusion barrier for balanced Li ion adsorption/desorption from pore to pore. And reducing the thickness of carbon nitride can facilitate Li+ transport ability33. As shown in Fig. 2c, the diffusion energy barrier of Li+ in PCN was only 0.24 eV, which was comparable to many inorganic solid-state electrolytes34. The Lewis-acid theory could explain the weaker adsorption behavior of PCN for Li+. The N atoms with an extra pair of electrons in CN can be regarded as electron-rich donors, which the filled p orbitals could adsorb Lewis acidic Li+ through acid-base interactions. From the 2D charge density differences of CN and PCN (Supplementary Fig. 10a, b), introducing H+ destroyed the pristine charge distribution in CN. Bader charge analysis revealed that the average N atom of PCN lost 0.03 e compared to the state of the N atom in the CN. The Valence Band Maximum (Supplementary Fig. 10c, d) of PCN decreases to −7.39 eV compared to the CN (−3.47 eV), and the weakened alkaline sites result in the weak binding energy to Li+.

To gain further insights into the role of the protective effect of PCN layer in preventing electrolyte molecule penetration, molecular dynamics simulations were performed (Supplementary Movie 1). The initial simulation setup comprised the electrolyte and PCN materials. To simulate a practical electrolyte environment (1 M LiTFSI in DOL/DME), 20 LiTFSI molecules dissolved in 142 DOL and 96 DME molecules for simulation model were selected (Fig. 2d). As depicted in Fig. 2e, f, the system reached equilibrium after 100 ps. Throughout the simulation process (Fig. 2g), it is observed that the PCN layer maintained its structural stability despite some fluctuations. Its structure remained intact, and no penetration of electrolyte molecules occurred. Therefore, PCN can effectively block electrolyte molecules while selectively allowing the permeation of Li ions under the driven by voltage.

Considering the necessity of achieving uniform dispersion of PCN nanosheet within polymers to form an inorganic-organic composite layer, various polymers were compared in terms of their ability to modify LMAs. Through comprehensive evaluation encompassing film-forming properties, contact angle measurements, Coulombic efficiency assessments, and other factors, PEO was selected as polymer components due to its excellent film-forming properties, appropriate resistance to swelling, and high ion conductivity (Supplementary Figs. 11–13). Thus, a dispersion with a certain concentration of PCN nanosheets, PEO and Li salt was scraped evenly onto the Li foil to obtain PCN-PEO@Li anodes. It is noteworthy that PCN nanosheets exhibit superior dispersion compared to g-C3N4, thereby facilitating the attainment of a homogeneous protective layer composition (Supplementary Fig. 14). The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image showed PCN-PEO protective layer was uniformly coated on the surface of Li foil (Supplementary Fig. 15a). The cross-section SEM image and corresponding elemental mapping images revealed that an average thickness of 2.3 μm PCN-PEO film tightly and uniformly sticked on the surface of Li metal (Supplementary Fig. 15b, c). Contact angle test was applied to characterize the wettability of the PCN-PEO@Li to the electrolyte. It turned out that PCN-PEO@Li exhibited a much smaller contact angle (12.0°) compared to bare Li foil (24.6°), which was beneficial to build a shorter ion transmission pathway (Supplementary Fig. 16). It was considered that an ideal protection layer for LMAs should possess high ionic conductivity and high Li+ transfer number. Therefore, a PCN-PEO membrane was prepared to measure the Li+ transport ability. The addition of uniformly dispersed PCN nanosheets was able to induce a unique grain refinement effect, which effectively reduced polymer grain size and further enhanced interfacial Li+ transport ability27,35. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements showed that a self-supporting PCN-PEO possessed a high ion conductivity of 5.67 × 10−5 S cm−1 at room temperature, which was much higher compared to 1.09 × 10−5 S cm−1 of g-C3N4-PEO film and 3.3 × 10−6 S cm−1 of pure PEO film (Supplementary Fig. 17). Besides, the PCN-PEO protective layer exhibited a high Li+ transfer number (0.49) benefiting from the high Li+-selective conduction of PCN nanosheet, which was also higher than that of g-C3N4-PEO (0.34) and pure PEO (0.19) (Supplementary Fig. 18). After adding a small amount of liquid electrolyte (LE) to match the actual working condition, the Li+ transfer number could be further improved to 0.67 (Supplementary Fig. 19).

The role of the PCN-PEO protective layer on lithium metal deposition was demonstrated through a series of experiments and theoretical simulations. As shown in the schematic (Fig. 3a), the existence of PCN-PEO protective layer could homogenize current density and Li+ flux distribution, enabling the dendrite-free Li plating/stripping. To verify the mechanism, a typical rough Cu foil model with numerous bumps was established via COMSOL simulations (Supplementary Fig. 20a). Inspiringly, it was found that a noticeable improvement due to covering a protective layer on Cu foil (Supplementary Fig. 20b). The simulation result showed that the current density was tented to distribute on the hollows of the Cu foil, indicating that Li metal would preferentially deposit on these hollows instead of the tips of Cu foil for PCN-PEO@Cu (Fig. 3b).Fig. 3Evolution of different electrodes with Li plating.
a Schematic illustration of Li plating behaviors of PCN-PEO@Cu. b COMSOL simulations of current density for PCN-PEO@Cu. SEM characterizations of (c) top view and (d) side view after Li plating at 0.5 mA cm−2 for 1 mAh cm−2, the scale bar of inner image was 200 nm. SEM characterizations of (e) top view and (f) side view after Li plating at 0.5 mA cm−2 for 6 mAh cm−2. The scale bar of inner image was 1 μm. SEM characterizations after Li plating at 0.5 mA cm−2 for (e) 1 mAh cm−2 (f) 6 mAh cm−2 for bare Cu electrode. g Schematic illustration of Li plating behaviors of bare Cu. h COMSOL simulations of current density for bare Cu. SEM characterizations of (i) top view and (j) side view after Li plating at 0.5 mA cm−2 for 1 mAh cm−2. SEM characterizations of (k) top view and (l) side view after Li plating at 0.5 mA cm−2 for 6 mAh cm−2.

And a uniform distribution of Li+ and local current density was obtained to induce a flat Li deposition behavior (Supplementary Fig. 21a). The SEM image of Li deposition further demonstrated the advantages of PCN-PEO protective layer. When 1 mAh cm−2 of Li was plated on the PCN-PEO@Cu electrodes, the deposited Li nuclei were evenly laid under the stable PCN-PEO layer, and no Li dendrite could be found on PCN-PEO@Cu electrode (Figs. 3c, d). Notably, the inner SEM image showed the hexagonal single crystal morphology ( ~ 200 nm) of deposited Li, which came from the high speed of interfacial Li transport36. This demonstrated that Li+ selective interface could promote the nucleation behavior of Li and further induce uniform deposition of Li. With increasing the deposition capacity (0.5 mA cm−2 for 12 h), a layer of metallic Li, with a thickness of 32.4 μm, was densely tiled on the PCN-PEO@Cu electrode (Fig. 3e, f). PCN-PEO layer could be observed homogeneously distributed on the surface of Li block (Supplementary Fig. 22).

As for bare Cu electrodes, Li+ tended to distribute and nucleate randomly on the surface, leading to Li dendrite growth and an unstable SEI layer (Fig. 3g). The simulation result of bare Cu displayed that uneven Li+ and current density concentration were induced by the coarse structure of the electrode, causing Li dendrites growth on the tips of Cu foil (Fig. 3h and Supplementary Fig. 21b). The SEM image showed that large Li particles with irregular-shaped Li dendrites were randomly distributed on the surface of the bare Cu electrode (Figs. 3i, j). Further increasing the deposited Li capacity to 6.0 mAh cm−2, a mass of Li dendrites accumulated on the bare Cu electrode surface and resulted in severe volume expansion (75.3 μm), which was more than twice of the thickness of PCN-PEO@Cu electrode (Fig. 3k, l).

These above results further confirmed that PCN-PEO protective layer was able to homogenize the current density and Li+ flux to achieve dendrite-free behavior. Based on the discussion above, it was obvious that covering Li metal with PCN-PEO protective layer could achieve uniform deposition of Li metal and inhibit the growth of Li dendrites, which would induce stable and efficient electrochemical performances.

Half-cell was assembled to better understand the electrodeposition processes of metallic Li. At a current density of 1 mA cm−2 and fixed areal capacity of 3.0 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 4a), a high average CE of 99.4% was achieved after 50 cycles for PCN-PEO@Cu electrode. Titration gas chromatography (TGC) test result showed that PCN-PEO@Cu electrodes had little dead Li (0.08%) during Li plating/striping process, indicating that PCN-PEO protective layer was beneficial to inducing uniform deposition of Li and inhibiting the formation of dead Li. As for bare Cu electrode, the symmetrical cell shorted out after running for 100 h caused by the Li dendrites. A sharp voltage dropped to −200.0 mV at the initial Li plating process for bare Cu electrodes and the overpotential was 100.0 mV (Fig. 4b), which was more than twice of the PCN-PEO@Cu electrodes (46.3 mV), indicating the PCN-PEO protective layer exhibited a smaller Li deposition barrier.Fig. 4Half-cell performance and analysis of interface layer.
a CE of bare Cu and PCN-PEO@Cu electrodes at 1.0 mA cm−2 for 3.0 mAh cm−2, and inset corresponding the reversible and irreversible Li (dead Li and SEI-Li) distribution of cells after test via TGC measurements. b Voltage-areal capacity curve corresponding to the nucleation process of bare Cu and PCN-PEO electrodes. The XPS depth profile of (c) C 1 s (d) N 1 s after plating 6 mAh cm−2 of Li metal. e XPS depth distribution of element content curve. f The TOF-SIMS depth distribution curve and (g) 3D view of Li−, TFSI−, C3N− and C2H4O− in the PCN-PEO protective layer.

Moreover, ex-situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was employed to analyze the chemical species of the electrode-electrolyte interphase on PCN-PEO@Cu anode after plating 6 mAh cm−2 of Li metal37. As shown in Fig. 4c–e, when the sputtering time was 0 s, the main signals came from PCN nanosheets, PEO, and TFSI- molecule, indicating the stability of PCN-PEO protective layer. With the increase of the etching time, the peaks of TFSI− anion disappeared while the content of Li+ continued to increase. These results confirmed that the PCN nanosheets could effectively block Li salt anions and selectively transport Li+. Alao, there was no obvious electrolyte decomposition product on the surface of Li metal. As for bare Cu electrode, the natural fragile organic SEI layer would consume a lot of electrolytes and be difficult to inhibit Li dendrite growth during the long cycle. The time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (TOF-SIMS) showed the uniform distribution of PCN nanosheets, PEO and Li salt in the protective layer. The content of TFSI- anion decreased with the deeper etching depth, while Li+ displayed a reversed distribution, verifying the high Li+-selective conduction of PCN-PEO protective layer (Figs. 4f, g).

Furthermore, a comprehensive characterization of the electrode structure was conducted to demonstrate the stability of the PCN-PEO layer. In the 50th cycle, the deposited Li on the PCN-PEO@Cu electrode still maintained an even and intact dendrite-free morphology (Supplementary Fig. 23a). After Li stripping, the PCN-PEO@Cu electrode exhibited a smooth surface (Supplementary Fig. 23b). In contrast, bare Cu electrodes showed the presence of Li dendrites and dead Li on their surface, leading to battery failure (Supplementary Fig. 23c, d). The in-depth XPS curve also confirmed the existence of PCN nanosheets on the electrode surface (Supplementary Fig. 24). Compared with other works, the PCN-PEO interface layer achieves low interface impedance, good electrolyte wettability, and favorable Li deposition morphology (Supplementary Table 3). These further emphasized the crucial role of the PCN-PEO protective layer in promoting uniform Li deposition during repeated Li plating/stripping processes.

The symmetrical cell with the PCN-PEO@Li electrodes exhibited steady and long Li plating/stripping cycle behaviors for more than 2000 h with a low overpotential of 16.1 mV at 1.0 mA cm−2 & 1.0 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 5a). In comparison, the symmetric cell with bare Li anode displayed a substantially larger overpotential (32.5 mV) with a much shorter cycle life. Even if the cycling capacity was markedly increased to 5.0 mAh cm−2 at 3.0 mA cm−2, PCN-PEO@Li electrodes achieved for more than 1800 h with, while short circuit happened for bare Li after 400 h (Fig. 5b). The comparison of overpotentials at different current densities also demonstrated the advantages of the PCN-PEO protective layer over g-C3N4 and pure Li foil (Supplementary Fig. 25a). Especially under a high current density of 5 mA cm−2, PCN-PEO@Li exhibited a smaller overpotential of 42.5 mV than that of g-C3N4-PEO layer (51.4 mV)and bare Li (94.3 mV), meeting the requirements for subsequent high energy density batteries (Supplementary Fig. 25b). Compared to symmetric cells with various inorganic artificial SEI modifications, Li metal modified with a PCN-PEO protective layer exhibited excellent stability (Supplementary Table 4)8,9,12,18,19,38,39.Fig. 5Electrochemical performance of PCN-PEO protective layer in coin cell.
a Cycle stability of symmetric cell employing bare Li and PCN-PEO@Li anodes at current densities of 1 mA cm−2 with areal capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. b Cycle stability of symmetric cell employing bare Li and PCN-PEO@Li anodes at current densities of 3 mA cm−2 with areal capacity of 5 mAh cm−2.Arrhenius plots of the resistance corresponding to (c) Li+ transport through SEI (d) charge transfer for PCN-PEO@Li and bare Li electrode. e Rate capability and (f) long-term cycling performance at 2.0 C of full cells pairing LFP cathodes with Bare Li and PCN-PEO@Li electrodes.

The activation energies of Li+ transport through SEI (Ea,SEI) and charge transfer (Ea,ct) were also calculated based on Arrhenius law (Supplementary Fig. 26 and Table 5)40. PCN-PEO@Li electrodes exhibited a lower Ea,SEI of −41.57 kJ mol−1 than that −50.63 kJ mol–1 of bare Li electrodes (Fig. 5c). Besides, the Ea,ct of PCN-PEO@Li electrodes (−41.40 kJ mol-1) was also lower than that of bare Li (−47.39 kJ mol−1), which could be ascribed to the fast charge transfer channel in PCN-PEO protective layer (Fig. 5d). Besides, Tafel plots demonstrated that the PCN-PEO@Li electrodes anode exhibited a substantially higher exchange current density of 0.44 mA cm−2 than that of bare Li electrode (0.25 mA cm−2), indicating a faster charge transfer process for PCN-PEO@Li electrodes anode (Supplementary Fig. 27). Benefiting from uniform Li plating/striping behavior of PCN-PEO@Li electrodes, the surface of the Li metal remained flat and clean (Supplementary Fig. 28a, b). In contrast, the surface of bare Li was covered with large Li dendrites and dead Li (Supplementary Fig. 28c). With cycle numbers increasing, Li dendrites continued to grow and thicken (Supplementary Fig. 28d).

Full cells were assembled to investigate the feasibility of practical applications. LiFePO4 was regarded as one of the most promising cathode materials for lithium-ion batteries due to its advantages of high safety, low cost, and long cycle life. Thus, full cells pairing LFP (1.8 mAh cm−2) cathodes with 50 μm PCN-PEO@Li anodes were assembled. Benefiting from the effects of the PCN-PEO protective layer, PCN-PEO@Li | |LFP cell showed an excellent rate capability (Fig. 5e). The reversible capacity slightly reduced to about 175.7, 169.6.1,152.1, 131.2, 118.7, and 79.5 mAh g-1 at different current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 5 C, respectively, while they were about 171.8, 169.4, 146.0, 119.0, 91.2, and 56.6 mAh g-1 at the same current rates in the bare Li | |LFP cell. Furthermore, PCN-PEO@Li | |LFP cell exhibited a stable cycling performance of more than 500 cycles at a high cycle rate of 2.0 C (Fig. 5f), with a capacity retention of 90% (from 122.4 to 110.2 mAh g-1). On the contrary, fast capacity decay occurred after 100 cycles for bare Li ||LFP cell due to the irreversible Li stripping/plating process and consumption of electrolyte.

sec.title: Li metal pouch cells with PCN-PEO layer
sec.p:
Benefiting from the scalability of this simple blade coating method, 324 Wh kg-1 CC-free Li-metal pouch cells with PCN-PEO protective layer were assembled, which could be further reached to ~380 Wh kg-1 excluding the mass of taps and packing foil. The detailed content of Li metal large scale modification, pouch cell design, assemble, and testing conditions were presented in the supplementary materials (Supplementary Figs. 29–31 and Table 6). It should be mentioned that choosing ultrathin Li foil instead of Li/Cu composite as anode could significantly increase the energy density of LMBs. However, during repeated plating/striping processes, the pulverization of Li foil could reduce the continuity of the electrode and thus cut off the electronic pathway, resulting in a significant capacity reduction of the pouch cell in a short period. The accumulation of side reaction products and dead Li would cause the loose structure of Li anode and increase of internal resistance. These factors made it difficult for cycle life of LMBs to exceed 100 cycles without the support of Cu CC (Supplementary Fig. 32). Due to the design of high Li+-selective conducting layer on Li foil, we had succeeded in achieving dense Li plating behavior and inhibiting side reactions effectively, thus leading to a long-life and high energy density Li metal pouch cell. As a result, the PCN-PEO@Li | |NCM523 pouch cell achieved more than 300 stable cycles with a capacity retention of 90.3% and average coulombic efficiency of 99.7% (Fig. 6a), while g-C3N4-PEO@Li | |NCM523 and bare Li | |NCM523 pouch cell appeared a sudden failure after 90 and 40 cycles (Supplementary Fig. 33). In addition, the PCN-PEO@Li pouch cell also showed steady charge/discharge curves during long-term cycling without an obvious change (Fig. 6b).Fig. 6Electrochemical performance of Li metal pouch cell.
a Cycling performance of 800 mAh pouch cell pairing NCM523 cathodes. b Charge/discharge curves of PCN-PEO@Li | |NCM523 pouch cell for different cycles. c Photos of PCN-PEO@Li and bare Li after 50 cycles. d Resistivity and thickness growth rate of different Li electrode compared to fresh Li after 50 cycles. e Discharge capacity retention at 0.1 C of PCN-PEO@Li | |NCM523 and bare Li | |NCM523 pouch cells at different temperature. f Cycling performance of 7-Ah-level NCM83 pouch cell at 0.1 C charge/0.5 C discharge with energy density of 506.7 Wh kg−1. g The comparison of reported performance > 300 Wh kg−1 CC-free Li metal pouch cells.

The pouch cell was disassembled after 50 cycles to analyze the decay mechanism of pouch cells. The photo showed that Li anode with PCN-PEO protective layer kept good planar structure, while lots of cracks and powdery situation on the surface of bare Li (Fig. 6c). The SEM image showed that the PCN-PEO@Li electrode kept an intact structure, and no obvious “dead Li” could be found on the surface (Supplementary Fig. 34a). In contrast, plenty of Li dendrites and dead Li were found on the surface of bare Li from SEM image (Supplementary Fig. 34b). Also, PCN-PEO@Li electrode exhibited a good structural integrity with lower resistance growth rate of 23.3% compared to 177.3% that of bare Li, ensuring PCN-PEO@Li electrode could also work as CC (Fig. 6d). Furthermore, the thickness measurements revealed that PCN-PEO@Li electrode owned a lower thickness change (15.6%) compared to that of bare Li electrode (65.2%), indicating PCN-PEO protective layer could effectively alleviate the volume expansion of Li metal anodes (Supplementary Fig. 34c, d). Low temperature charge/discharge performance of Li metal pouch cell was also tested. As a result, higher capacity retentions could be achieved by coating PCN-PEO protective layer at various temperatures (Fig. 6e). Specifically, a ~ 500 mAh PCN-PEO@Li pouch cell maintained a high discharge capacity of 380.6 mAh at −20 °C and 325.7 mAh at −30 °C (Supplementary Fig. 35a), while bare Li pouch cell could only discharge 326.9 mAh at −20 °C and 268.4 mAh at −30 °C (Supplementary Fig. 35b). The EIS spectra showed that PCN-PEO protective layer could accelerate the transportation of Li+ and thus reduce interface impedance (Supplementary Fig. 35c).

Moreover, a 506.7 Wh kg−1 NCM83 Li metal pouch was further assembled to verify the superiority of PCN-PEO protective layer by paring higher areal capacity NCM83 cathode (6.0 mAh cm−2) and adding less electrolyte (1.2 g Ah-1) (Supplementary Fig. 36 and table 7). The PCN-PEO@Li | |NCM83 pouch cell maintained a high energy density of 483.4 Wh kg-1 after 100 cycles and successfully achieved 160 cycles with a capacity retention of 80% (Fig. 6f). In contrast, the bare Li and g-C3N4-PEO@Li electrode failed after 40 cycles and 60 cycles, respectively, indicating the high stability and reliability of PCN-PEO@Li electrodes (Supplementary Fig. 37). In comparison to other lately reported Li metal pouch cell with artificial SEI layer (Supplementary Table 8)41–44, PCN-PEO protective layer Li metal pouch cell exhibited a remarkable high energy density and cycling performance (Fig. 6g)45–54. Through the above comparison, PCN-PEO@Li pouch cell showed a record-high in terms of both energy density and cycle life performance compared to other works, illustrating the superiority of a macroscopically uniform interface layer with Li+ conductive channels for high stability and high energy density Li metal pouch cell.

In summary, the long cycle performance of CC-free Li metal pouch cell has been successfully achieved by covering a macroscopically uniform and selectively Li+ conducting PCN-PEO interface layer on Li foil surface. Benefiting from the increased number of micropores and lower Li+ migration barriers, PCN nanosheets exhibit better Li+ transport properties compared to g-C3N4. It is demonstrated that PCN-PEO protective layer with macroscopically uniform interface composition is advantageous for achieving homogeneous fluxes of Li+, blocking the side reaction between electrolyte with Li metal and inducing even deposition of Li metal. As a result, symmetrical cell using PCN-PEO@Li electrodes exhibits stable cycling and high Li utilization. The assembled 324 Wh kg−1 CC-free pouch cell exhibit 300 stable cycles with a capacity retention of 90.3%. Impressively, the high energy density with 506 Wh kg−1 PCN-PEO@Li | |NCM83 pouch cell was successfully assembled, for which 160 stable cycles could be realized. This work could be instructive to design high-performance Li metal anode without copper CC for long cycle life and high energy density Li metal cell.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Polyethylene oxide (PEO, Mv~300000), lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulphonyl)imide (LiTFSI, 99.9%) melamine (99.9%), and concentrated hydrochloric acid were purchased from Alfa Aesar and Aladdin and used without further purification. The Copper (Cu, 99.9%), aluminum (Al, 99.9%) current collectors poly(vinylidene fluoride), cathode materials, and Li foils (99.95%) separator (Celgard 2325) were supplied by Canrd New Energy Technology Co.,Ltd. The detailed materials for assembling pouch cell were listed in the table below.

sec.title: Preparation of g-C3N4 powder
sec.p: g-C3N4 powder was easily prepared by the modified thermal polymerization of melamine. Briefly, 5 g melamine powder was placed in a tube furnace (Thermo Scientific) and heated at 550 °C (ramping rate of 5 °C min−1) for 2 h under Ar protection. The product was further heated at 600 °C for 5 h under air conditions to exfoliate bulk g-C3N4. Finally, g-C3N4 powder was obtained by washing twice with Ethanol and distilled water. The final g-C3N4 were dried at 60 °C under vacuum for further use.

sec.title: Preparation of protonated C3N4 (PCN) nanosheets
sec.p: PCN nanosheets was synthesized through the processes of protonation and exfoliation. Typically, 0.1 g of yellow g-C3N4 powder was added into 15 mL of 35 wt% HCl solution with intense agitation at 45 °C. Afterwards, the milky white mixture was filtrated followed by washing twice with water to remove redundant HCl. Subsequently, the protonated C3N4 was redisperse in 30 mL distilled water and sonicated in a conical tube with a sonic tip for 3 h at the power of 350 W. The ultrasound probe worked 3 s with the interval of 3 s. Finally, PCN nanosheets was obtained by freeze drying of the above dispersion.

sec.title: Preparation of PCN-PEO@Li electrode
sec.p: Typically, 250 mg of PCN nanosheets were first dispersed in 10 ml anhydrous acetonitrile by bath ultrasound. Then, 250 mg PEO and LiTFSI (Li+: [EO] = 1:15) were dissolved into the above homogeneous solution and further stirred for 12 h at room temperature to obtain PCN-PEO slurry. To prepare PCN-PEO@Li electrode, Li foil was placed on a glass plate and PCN-PEO slurry was evenly spread by blade coating. After acetonitrile completely volatilizing, lithium foil was die cut to the desired size. Similarly, PCN-PEO@Cu electrode was prepared in the same way using Cu foil as current collector. And all the process was operated in an Ar-filled glove box with O2 and H2O content below 0.1 ppm. The large-scale electrode preparation process was discussed in detail in Figure S30.

sec.title: Ionic conductivity test
Assembly of coin cell and electrochemical test
sec.p: All coin cells were assembled as CR2025 type coin cells in an Ar-filled glove box with O2 and H2O content below 0.1 ppm. 40 μl electrolyte of 1.0 M LiTFSI in DOL/DME (1:1 by volume) was used in assembling all the coin cells except as otherwise noted. LFP cathodes with different areal capacities 1.8 mAh cm−2 were prepared by mixing LFP powders, Super C carbon black and PVDF binder with a mass ratio of 90:5:5 in NMP and coating the slurry onto Al foil. The Li|LiFePO4 full cells were operated in a voltage window of 2.2–4.0 V. All coin cells were tested in Land CT3001A battery tester at 25 °C. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement was performed on CHI 760E electrochemical workstation.

sec.title: Assembly of the Li metal pouch cells
sec.p: The Li metal pouch cell was assembled in the dry room (Dew point temperature below −50, 25 °C). The cell assembly was performed with a semi-automatic laminator (SHENZHEN KEJING STAR TECHNOLOGY CO., LTD. MSK-111A-L), which comprises a Z-stacking machine. The electrolyte was prepared by LiDFOB (0.6 M) and LiBF4 (0.6 M) in fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC) (v/v = 1:2). As for other design details can be obtained in Supplementary Table S4 and Table S5. Before long-term cycling, the pouch cells were cycled at 0.1 C for one cycle to form a stable solid electrolyte interface. The cells were monitored in a LAND multichannel battery cycler (Wuhan LAND Electronics Co., Ltd.) at 25 °C and test voltage range is 3.0–4.3 V. Meanwhile, it is necessary to apply certain pressure (0.25 Mpa) during the charge and discharge process.

sec.title: Titration gas chromatography
sec.p: Titration gas chromatography (TGC) test was applied to determine the amount of inactive Li (Li0) after cell cycling tests. Specifically, after Li stripping for a certain number of cycles, the coin cell was firstly disassembled in an Ar-filled glovebox. Then the electrodes were harvested without washing and further sealed in a container with an inside pressure of 1 atm by a rubber septum which was stable against water. Subsequently, the sample container was transferred out of the glovebox and 1.0 ml of H2O was injected into the container to react with the inactive Li. After reacting completely, a gas-tight syringe was used to transfer 1 mL of the resultant gas from the container into the gas chromatography (GC) system to measure the amount of H2. Finally, the content of the metallic Li0 was determined by a pre-established standard H2 calibration curve.

sec.title: Theoretical calculation
sec.p: The projector augmented wave (PAW) formalism of density functional theory as implemented in the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) was used in the system energy and electronic structure calculations1. The Gaussian smearing method was used and the width of smearing was chosen as 0.05 eV. The energy cutoff for plane-wave expansion of the PAWs is 500 eV. In the vertical direction, a vacuum layer of about 15 Å in thickness was introduced for all the surfaces. For the adsorption energy and adsorption conformation simulations, we used the DFT-D3 functional to include the physical van der Waals interaction2. The adsorption energy (Ead) of Li is defined as Ead = ET − E0 − ELi, where E0 is the energy of the surface of CN or PCN, ET is the energy of the corresponding system with Li+ adsorbed, ELi is the energy of Li+, respectively. The larger the negative value of Ead, the stronger the interaction between the adsorption systems. It should be emphasized that we have taken into account the electron deficient system energy of protonation and lithium ions through the adjustment of the NELECT parameter. The Brillouin zone was sampled using the Monkhorst-Pack scheme with a k-point mesh of 3 × 3 × 1 in the Gamma-centered grids for the structural relaxation3. The structure relaxation was continued until the forces on all the atoms converged to less than 0.01 eV/Å. The decomposition barrier for Li+ was determined by Climbing Image-Nudged Elastic Band4.

Molecular dynamics simulations were conducted using the Forcite module in Materials Studio. The simulations were performed in the isothermal-isobaric (NPT) ensemble with constant particles (N), a temperature of 298.15 K, and a pressure of 1 atm. The COMPASS force field was applied to describe the interactions among the atoms in the ensemble. Temperature and pressure were controlled using the Nose thermostat and Berendsen barostat, respectively. The total simulation time was 1000 ps with a time step of 1 fs.

sec.title: Materials characterization
sec.p: The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-obtained samples were obtained using a Bruker X-ray diffractometer (D8 Advance) with Cu Kα radiation. SEM images were captured on a Hitachi SU8020 instrument. For postmortem analyses, including SEM and XPS measurements, cycled coin cells were dissembled in the Ar-filled glovebox to collect electrodes. XPS measurements were conducted on the ESCALAB 250Xi, (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA) equipped with Ar+ ion etching (2 kV; 2 µA). Depth profiling and chemical analysis data of the sample were collected on a TOF-SIMS instrument (IONTOF GmbH, Germany 2010). The data were recorded in ultrahigh vacuum at a pressure of 10−9 Torr in a negative model. The Ar Ion Gun was selected as ion species with 3 KV 100 nA. The sputter area was 400 µm X 400 µm with rate of ~10 nm/min on SiO2. Brunner-Emmet-Teller (BET) measurements were obtained using Micromeritics ASAP 2460.

sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1038/s41467-024-54310-1.

ack.p: Q. Chen, B. Gao, Z. Yang, and Y. Li contributed equally to this work. Y. Gong was supported by the National Key Technologies R&D Program of China (Grant Nos. 2022YFB2404300), the National Natural Science Foundation of China (22171016), the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities and the 111 Project (B17002), Key R&D Program of Zhejiang (2024SSYS0081). Q. Chen was supported by the Academic Excellence Foundation of BUAA for PhD Students.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: Y.G. supervised the project. Q.C., B.G., Z.Y, and Y.G. conceived the project and designed the experiments. Y.L., Q.Zhai, and C.Y. assembled Li metal pouch cell. Y.J., Q. Zhang, X.G., J.Z., and L.W., performed the characterization experiments. P.Z. performed the theoretical calculation. Q.C., T.W., P.Z., and Y.G. wrote the manuscript. All authors discussed the results and commented on the manuscript.

sec.title: Peer review information
sec.p: Nature Communications thanks Pascale Chenevier and the other, anonymous, reviewers for their contribution to the peer review of this work. A peer review file is available.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: All data are available in the main text or the Supplementary Information, which can also be available from the corresponding authors upon request. Source data are provided with this paper.

notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
